title: China Eximbank provides $67.629 million loan for Cuimba Agro-Industrial Development Project
description: On May 9, 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Angola signed a $67,629,060 loan agreement for the Cuimba Agro-Industrial Development Project. The borrowing terms of this loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to partially finance a $79,563,100 commercial contract with China CAMC Engineering Co. Ltd..   This project involved the development of a 3,000 hectare farm in Cuimba in Zaire Province. More specifically, it involved farmland reclamation and supporting irrigation facilities; construction of plant transportation infrastructure, operating roads and field workstations, pump stations and corn warehousing/drying/processing equipment; provision of vehicles and farming instruments required for production at the farm; construction of frozen processing plants, breeding farms, hatcheries, and feedstuff plants; other auxiliary facilities; and trial production of agricultural products and staff training.  China CAMC Engineering Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced in August 2014.  The farm will be 3,000 hectares and will produce grains and it was officially handed over to the Angolan authorities on December 10, 2019.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Guimba Agro-Industrial Development Project.The Chinese project title is 安哥拉库茵巴综合农场项目 or 安哥拉综合农场 or 安哥拉库茵巴农场.The Portuguese project title is Projecto de Desenvolvimento Agro-Industrial do Cuimba, na Província do Zaire.

title: CITIC Construction provides grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at Agostinho Neto University
description: On 1 March 2014, Agostinho Neto University, Hanban, Harbin Normal University, and CITIC Construction Co. signed a cooperation protocol regarding the establishment of a Confucius Institute at Agostinho Neto University. CITIC Construction Co. provided a grant of an unspecified value for this project.    The new Confucius Institute is located at Agostinho Neto University in the suburbs of Luanda. Hanban helped finance and organize this project and Harbin Normal University was the partner institution. This project involved the construction of buildings housing classrooms, faculty apartments, a library, and a multi-function hall. CITIC Construction Co. was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on 6 February 2015, and the opening ceremony took place more than two years later on 14 September 2016.   The Confucius Institute at Neto University is the first Confucius Institute established in Angola and the first Confucius Institute in the world to be jointly established by a Chinese company. In addition to investing in the construction of the teaching building of the Confucius Institute, CITIC Construction will also support and participate in the teaching and management of the future college.

title: CDB extends $2.5 billion master facility agreement to Angola in May 2014
description: On May 9, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) entered into a $2.5 billion master facility agreement with the Government of Angola.   The agreement is a master agreement under which the Government of Angola and CDB may conclude individual loan agreements (ILAs) for the purpose of financing up to 85% of the contract price owing to certain approved contractors in respect of certain approved infrastructure projects in Angola, primarily in the areas of housing, transportation, agriculture, roads and railways, hospitals, schools, telecommunication, water and electricity, sanitation and other human livelihood areas agreed by CDB and Angola. Each individual (subsidiary) loan approved through the facility must be for a minimum of $10 million and have a maturity of 10 years.   As of December 31, 2017, $2,199,500,000 was drawn down under the MLFA. The (principal) amount outstanding under the MLFA was $300.5 million as of December 31, 2017 and $2.1 billion as of December 31, 2021. The availability period for drawdowns under this master facility agreement ended on May 9, 2017. However, it was later extended until 2021.   Projects that may have been funded through the master facility agreement include: 1. Construction of access roads to Luanda International Airport (Project ID#65307) 2. Rehabilitation of New Luanda International Airport (Project ID#72349)  There are indications that the May 2014 CDB loan financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In December 2020, CDB and the Government of Angola entered into an agreement to reprofile multiple loan agreements that they had previously signed, including the $15 billion loan agreement from December 2015. The December 2020 agreement included (i) a three-year deferral of principal payments; and (ii) repayment of deferred principal falling due in 2020H2–2023H1 over seven years after the grace period, with some additional modest relief of principal in 2024–25. The Government of Angola also agreed to use the outstanding cash balance in an escrow account — known as the Debt Service Reserve Account (DSRA) — to make interest payments to the CDB between 2020 to 2022, which it expected would bring the DSRA balance to nearly zero by mid-2022. However, under the terms of the debt reprofiling agreement, the parties agreed that the borrower would need to replenish the DSRA to approximately $1.5 billion (the minimum cash balance previously agreed upon by the lender and borrower) by 2023.
staff_comments: 1. This project is not categorized as an umbrella record because the full amount of the facility was disbursed. However, AidData was not able to identify all of the subsidiary loans and the face values of all subsidiary loans approved through this facility. Therefore, to eliminate the risk of double counting, AidData does not record transaction amounts for the subsidiary loans. Instead, it records the amount that the borrower drew down ($2,199,500,000) from this facility.2. According to China Development Bank's website, it provided Angola's Ministry of Finance with a $4 billion ‘sovereign loan’, which is a specific type of loan that only CDB issues (Chinese name: 主权类外汇贷款). It is likely that this $2.5 billion credit line (MLFA) is part of the $4 billion sovereign loan that is referenced. The remaining $1.5 billion is likely captured via Project ID#67.3. Given that CDB agreed to issue individual loans to finance up to 85% of the cost of commercial contracts, AidData assumes that these individual loans were issued in the form of buyer's credits. This issue warrants further investigation. 4. The loan's interest rate and grace period are unknown. For the time being, AidData relies on the interest rate (3.7873%) and grace period (1.9008 years) identified in the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS) for official sector Chinese lending to Angola in 2014. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0

title: ICBC provides $120 million loan for Phase 1 of Futungo de Belas Project
description: In November 2014, the President of Angola issued a decree (Presidential Decree No. 224/14), approving a $120 million loan agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) for Phase 1 of Futungo de Belas Project. The borrowing terms of this loan are unknown. The borrower was allowed to use the proceeds of this loan to finance a $150 million commercial contract with CITIC Construction, which was signed on June 15, 2011.  The project involves the development of sports, tourism, housing and trade facilities on a 537 hectares site that is located about 11 kilometers outside the city of Luanda. It also involves the construction and maintenance of logistics infrastructure, including drinking water, electricity and sanitation facilities.  A foundation laying ceremony for this project took place on July 11, 2011. The project was still being implemented in 2017 and 2018. However, it is not clear whether or when the project reached completion.
staff_comments: 1. The project is also known as the Angola National Tourism Area Project.2. The Portuguese project title is Perímetro Desanexado do Futungo de Belas - Fase I.3. The Chinese project title is 安哥拉国家旅游区项目.4. In the the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it identifies a $31 million CDB loan in 2016 for this project. However, it does not record the $120 million ICBC loan that was contracted in 2014. AidData has not identified any official sources that corroborate the provision of a $31 million CDB loan, so for the time being it only records the $120 million loan from ICBC.

title: China trains Angolan officials on gaming/gambling industry management
description: From May 12, 2014, to May 17, 2014, at the request of the Angolan Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the Permanent Secretariat of the China-Portugal Forum, China’s gaming/gambling industry management training course for Angola was held at the Gaming Supervision and Coordination Bureau of the Special Administrative Region (SAR) Macao. Six people, including Joao Guibiba, Director of the Research and International Relations Office of the Ministry of Finance of Angola, attended the training. The training was meant to help the Angolan government learn from the management of gaming/gambling in Macao for Angola's growing domestic gaming/gambling industry.

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Luanda General Hospital Sewage System Rehabilitation Project (linked to Umbrella #53184)
description: On 24 March, 2014 and 9 June, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government Angola signed letters of exchange for the Luanda General Hospital Sewage System Rehabilitation Project. The Chinese Ministry of Commerce provided a grant of an unspecified value for this project.   This project involved increasing the hospital sewage treatment design standards, installing high-quality sewage treatment equipment, and installing a new piping system. The Beijing Institute of Architectural Design was responsible for planning and design and China Railway Fourth Bureau (CREC4) was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was officially handed over to the Angolan authorities on 26 February 2015.  The Chinese Government made several other financial commitments to the Luanda General Hospital Rehabilitation and Expansion Project (see Umbrella Project #53184).
